original: saṃpūjyate vajragītyā locanādibhir gīyate abhiṣicyamāno mūrdhāyāṃ herukaniṣpannaḥ trisandhyādhiṣṭhānabhāvanāṃ vibhāvyottiṣṭhet devatāmūrtyā sthātavyam devīnāṃ tu atrāprādhānyāt rūpasvabhāvena saṃvṛtyāpi pādeṣu tadviṣayāṇīndriyāṇi cittasaṃprayuktā rāgādayaścaittikaṃ ṣaṣṭho viṣayaḥ ṣaḍviṣayavijñānāni vijñānamuttara ॰vijñānaviśeṣotpattyān tattvapaṭalaḥ pañcamaḥ utpannakramaṃ nirdeṣṭumāha–tattvapaṭalamityādi atha tattvapaṭalaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ|

original: svarūpeṇa nāsti rūpamiti rūpaṃ rūpasvabhāvena śūnyam tattvata iti sāmarthyādavaga- ntavyaṃ tattvasyedānīṃ vyākhyāyamānatvāt na tu saṃvṛtyāpi rūpaṃ nāsti evamuttareṣvapi pādeṣu svarūpeṇeti padamanuvartya yathāyogaṃ vaktavyam tatra rūpādayaḥ pañca viṣayāḥ draṣṭrādayastu pañca tadviṣayāṇīndriyāṇi cittasaṃprayu- ktā rāgādayaścaittikaṃ ṣaṣṭho viṣayaḥ cittaṃ tu ṣaḍviṣayavijñānāni manaindriyaṃ ca tatra manaindriyaṃ cakṣurādīndriyavat pṛthag nāsti anantarātītameva tu vijñānamuttaravijñā- rūpādayaḥ pañca viṣayā manaāyatanaṃ ceta utpannakramaṃ rūpasvabhāvena saṃvṛtyāpi pādeṣu tadviṣayāṇīndriyāṇi cittasaṃprayuktā rāgādayaścaittikaṃ ṣaṣṭho viṣayaḥ ṣaḍviṣayavijñānāni manaindriyaṃ vijñānamuttara tattvapaṭalaḥ pañcamaḥ naviśeṣotpattyādhipatyānmanaindriyamucyate tadevaṃ dvādaśāyatanānyuktāni rūpāyatanaṃ cakṣurāyatanaṃ yāvaddharmāyatanaṃ manaāyatanaṃ ceti|

original: abimbetyādi sattvam bijākṣaram, bimbam cihnam tābhyām samudbhūtam maṇḍaleśam iti maṇḍalanāyakam, nairātmyām ity arthaḥ f nāyakotpā akṣaramādyakṣaram | tadbhavasya pindasyeti manda bimbam cihnam evam bhagavatyāḥ skandhadhātvāyataneṣu bījanyāsam kṛtvā, padmavajrādhiṣṭhā- nam kuryāt āḥkāreṇa' tridalam padmam āhlādakaram dhyātvā, hūṁkāreṇa kamalakośakiñ- jalkaśuṣiram vicintya, tadanu hūṁkārasambhūtam vajram vibhāvya, oṁkāreṇa tanmaṇiśuṣiram ca dhyātvā, mantreṇānenādhitisthet-om padma sukhādhāra mahārāga sukhamdada | caturā- nandabhag viśva hūṁ hūṁ hūṁ kāryam kuruṣva me|| om vajra mahādveṣa caturānandadāyaka | khagamukhaikaraso nātha hūṁ kāryam kuruşva me||' bahyamudrābhāve manonirmitām mu- drām prāpya, tasyāṇ ca pañcakulakalāpakramādikam ca kṛtvā, anurāgaṇam ārabhet—‘oṁ sar- vatathāgatānurāgaṇavajrātmakāḥ sarvadharmāḥ | om sarvatathāgatānurāgaṇavajrasvabhāvāt- mako 'ham ||' iti kṛtvā, vāgvajrāhaṇkāreṇa hūṁkāram uccārayan vajram cālayet śūnyatād- himoksādi ratisukhaparyantenādiyogo nama samādhih etac ca prajñopāyaikarasamahāsukhasambhavabodhicittam phaṭkāravinirgatam niścitya pūjām kuryād anena-om sarvatathāgatapūjāvajrasvabhāvātmakāḥ sarvadharmāḥ | om sarvatathagat- apūjāvajrasvabhāvātmako 'ham' iti paṭhitvā, garuḍamudrādharo yogi kamalakośāntargatam tad bodhicittam rasanendriyeṇa gṛhītvā sarvatathāgatavajrayoginīsvabhāvam ātmānam pūjayet yadi suśikṣitā syāt mudrā no cen na kartavyam anyathā mūlāpattiḥ syāt arthaḥ upalakṣaṇam caitac, ity arthaḥ candraprabham pṛthak pṛthag iti anyasyā anyasyā ity arthaḥ yoginīr iti bhāvayed iti sambandhaḥ yoginīḥ kaṇṭhā pañcabuddhaviśuddhena viśuddheneti viśuddhyā śuddheti śuddhāḥ mudrakā iti mudrāḥ tathā cakram bhāvayet tasya siddhir āśu bhaviṣyati ||

original: tattvabhāvana may be read as a bahuvrīhi and the overall sense of this verse will not be greatly affected: 'So they whose meditation is reality should see things'.

I believe, however, the tantra more strongly implies that one should read 'tattvabhāvanaiḥ' as equivalent to 'tattvab- hāvanābhiḥ', the change of gender for bhāvanā (and its plural form) being to accommodate the metre.
The same usage in HeTa is much more difficult to interpret as a bahuvrīhi.

original: This absence of being one or many becomes, from a single moment, supreme enjoyment.
1.8.50 is a division of insight and means on an intermediate level (avāntaram), like [the timate [reality] (paramārtha).

As [the Blessed One] will teach: 'Therefore, bliss is not reality, For just that reason, [the Blessed One] teaches the ultimate state of having on the innermost level (āntaram) the nature of insight and means beginning with '[This absence of being] one' 'Absence of being one or many' (ekānekaviyoga) is emptiness of an intrinsic nature (svabhāvaśūnyatā).
[It be- comes] 'supreme enjoyment' (parā rati), meaning unsurpassed bliss—that is to
say, it becomes Great Bliss empty of an intrinsic nature.
'From a single moment' means in the single moment of vilakṣaṇa [i.e. the moment associated with Innate Bliss].
Since [the Blessed One] wishes to express causality with regard to [the vilakṣaṇa moment which is] none other than a locus, he [uses the fifth case and] says 'from [a single] moment'.
That has been taught [elsewhere]: 'Although similar to space, ah!-it is cool and sweet'
In some [manuscripts] there is the reading ‘ekā', [i.e. 'This absence of being one and many, from a moment, dicates a preference.
Evidence from previous verses-namely 1.8.26d (tatsukham cakram ucyate) and 1.8.29b/d (śukram tasya sukham ca vā)-suggests a genitive tatpuruşa understanding may be most fitting.
analyzed: evidence from previous verse tad sukham cakram ucyate and d śukra tasya sukham ca vā suggests a genitive tatpuru a understanding may be most fitting

original: tary, while he too recognises the alternative reading, ‘kṣaṇād ekā parā ratiḥ.
analyzed: tarī while he too recognises the alternative reading kṣaṇāt ekā parā ratiḥ

original: Since Kamalanātha gives preference to the former, I have printed it in the edition and translated it here.

Addressing this, [the Blessed One] says '[For, the process of] empowerment' and so on.

The process of em- powerment (adhiṣṭhānakrama) is that self-empowerment which is [performed] according to key instructions at the time of consecration (seka) and so on, [and that process] is completely beyond the path of words (vākpathātīta).

'The knowl- edge of the omniscient one has that as its nature' means that the knowledge of the omniscient one (sarvajñajñāna) too has precisely that [self-experienced knowl- edge that is beyond the activity of words] as its nature (tanmaya).
Therefore, what opportunity is there here for words?
[Although it is ineffable,] nevertheless merely a brief teaching is hinted at, beginning with ‘Earth’.

original: kiñjalkam And [the yogin who is] of insight and means is not undermined by arising and dissolution, since arising is means, and dissolution is in- sight, which brings an end to cyclic existence
2.2.27 ‘Of insight and means' refers to the yogin who, having insight and means as his nature, is perfected in the Great Seal
Arising and cessation do not undermine him as they do these mundane people
utpāda) [and] dissolution (laya = pralaya), i.e. cessation (nirodha), are none other than the essential nature of existent things
So, how can they undermine [a perfected yogin], since both [arising and dissolution], insofar as they are of a single flavour, do not exist as they are imagined?
For just this reason, [the Blessed One] says 'Thus' and so on: Thus, in reality, there exists no dissolution for him, and certainly no arising
A person dissolves because of dissolution; but because he has no dissolution, there is no destruction
2.2.28 For this [perfected yogin], arising and dissolution do not exist in reality; mun- dane people, however, think that they do
[The Blessed One] shows precisely that: ‘A person', i.e
someone were he to have an intrinsic nature, ‘dissolves be- cause of dissolution'; but how could a person possibly dissolve who, in having no essential nature, is nobody at all?
Therefore, because this [perfected yogin] lacks dissolution, [for him] there is also 'no destruction' (kṣaya = uccheda)

As an illusion, as a dream, and as the intermediary state-so the mandala appears through yoga with constant practice
2.2.30 Showing that this [complexity-free form also] has the nature of great bliss, tions]' and so on

original: Kamalanatha's Ratnāvalī Hevajrapañjikā Black is bliss; yellow is bliss; red is bliss; white is bliss; green is bliss; blue is bliss-everything animate and inanimate is bliss
2.2.32 Insight is bliss, means is bliss; what arises from olibanum is bliss; ex- istence is bliss, non-existence is bliss; Vajrasattva is known to be bliss
'What arises from olibanum (kunduru) is bliss' means other blisses [are also bliss]
'Existence,' arising, birth, and expan- sion are synonyms; 'non-existence, cessation, death, and contraction are [also] synonyms, [and] they are bliss

blue, yellow, and so forth; which takes on the form of deities in union; which is differentiated in terms of the [fourfold] classification of Bliss, [Supreme Bliss], and so on; and which has the nature Vajrasattva in doing expansion and contrac- tion in the form of birth/death and arising/cessation—is completely suffused with Great Bliss
So, what is the point of meditating on a mandala circle?
Just this Great Bliss should be recollected in its arisen form.'
To address this, [Vajra- garbha] says '[This is the yoga of the stage of the arisen]' and so on: Vajragarbha asked: This is the yoga of the stage of the arisen
Great Bliss is held to be the genuine bliss

original: Kamalanātha treats sandhyābhāṣā as feminine noun, in contrast to the tantra
In his MuĀ Ratnākaraśānti treats it as a masculine noun (and once, in ad 2.3.55, as a neuter noun)
The Blessed One responded: 2.3.55 'Madana' means alcohol, 'bala' meat, and 'malayaja' gathering
'Kheṭa' means going, ‘śrāpa’ corpse, and ‘niramśuka' bone ornaments
2.3.56 ‘Preńkhaṇa' means returning, O wise one, and ‘kṛpīța” is held to refer to a rattle drum
'Dundura' refers to an unfit participant, while 'kāliñjara' is held to refer to a fit participant
2.3.57 ‘Diṇḍima' is said to mean untouchable, and ‘padmabhājana' skull
analyzed: diṇḍima is untouchable padma bhājana skull

original: 'Tṛptikara' is understood to mean food, while ‘mālatīndhana' refers to curry (vyañjana)
2.3.58 ‘Catuḥsama' is said to refer to faeces, and ‘kastūrikā' is traditionally known to refer to urine
'Sihla(ka) is known to refer to menstrual blood, while ‘karpūra(ka) is held to refer to śukra
2.3.59 “Šālija' is said to refer to great (i.e
human) flesh, and ‘kunduru' the union of two faculties
'Bola(ka) refers to a vajra, and ‘kakkola' is held to refer to a lotus
analyzed: bola ka a vajra kakkola is held refer a lotus

original: 2.3.60 The families are said to be five, divided based on the types of social classes
Based entirely on the coded communication, the five buddhas belong to the five families
2.3.61 525 Kṛṣṇa clarify that they are the kriyā, caryā, yoga, and yogottara tantras
analyzed: kṛṣṇa clarify that they are the kriyā caryā yoga and yogottara tantras
